Yesterday we received a letter from SAC
chairman Ron Bialek stating that the SAC
executive committee recommends the
News-Letter be denied SAC funds for the
'76-'77 academic year. All decisions will be
finalized next Wednesday afternoon at a
general SAC meeting in the Great Hall at
5:00 P.M.
The News-Letter's annual expenditures
total approximately $30,000. Eighty per
cent of that sum is obtained through
advertising; the remainder has traditionally
been supplied by the SAC, the group which
funds all Hopkins student organizations. In
order for the paper to survive financially,
the $6,000 is essential.
This is not the first ^time that the
News-Letter has had difficulty in
bargaining for these funds. Last May, after
several heated arguments, the News-Letter
was awarded $5500. In that case, the SAC
questioned whether the paper should have
any paid employees. They insisted that no
staff member, in any capacity, should be
paid for their efforts. They were sure that
most people would continue to work
stripped of salary, out of their dedication
to the paper.
We felt then, as we do now, that this
rationale is not only naive but invalid as
well. First of all, very few staff members
are paid for their services. Those who do
get paid are involved in the technical aspect
of the News-Letter, the behind-the-scenes
drudgery that is necessary to produce any
newspaper. These paid staffers work on
paste-up, typing, distribution and similar
tasks. There is no glory in this kind of
work, no by-lines or picture credits. And
not everyone in this category is paid--we
just can't afford it.
Furthermore, the wages are nowhere
near the king's ransom that the SAC feels
we are handing out. A production assistant
is paid fifteen dollars an issue. Usually they
work from ten in the evening until seven
the next morning. Even with salaries, we
are short on help; if salaries are eliminated,
few will toil for the News—Letter. And
justifiably so.
Unlike most college papers, the
News-Letter offers not a penny to its
editors. No one at the News—letter is
rewarded with academic credit for his or
her work.
This time around with the SAC,
however, there are other conflicts as well.
The SAC executive committee is convinced
the the News-Letter is shirking its
obligation to the student body because of
the content of this year's paper. They say
that the News-Letter should be primarily
an informative publication, one that deals

mainly with student news. Ron Bialek has
said that "the News-Letter's only
accomplishment this year has been to hurt
the jHU undergraduates."
What they really mean to say is that the
News-Letter has ceased to be merely a
publicity organ for the student government
and administration.
In particular, the SAC executive
committee is displeased with the Friday
editions of the News- Letter claiming
that a "magazine-features" format has no
place on a college campus. They describe
the paper as "too literary and cavalier," or
"filled with bullshit." They maintain that a
majority of the student body is dissatisfied
with the Friday News-Letter, suggested by
mythical stacks of leftover papers.
Well, these charges just aren't true. Not
only has the News-Letter increased
circulation this year, but by our estimates
-more people arc reading the News-Letter
today than at any time in its eighty year
history.
We have received,unprecedented acclaim
from a broad mixture of students, faculty,
administration, and community residents.
It is clear to us that the News-Letter is
more popular today than ever before. At
the very least, the constituency of the
News-Letter has changed. Last year's critics
are supporters, while our current detractors
are former friends of the paper. A
newspaper never has unanimous approval.
We have enough problems simply
producing the paper without additional
burdens thrust upon us by the SAC. We
have scores of critics, none of whom are
willing to work at the News-Letter to help
enact their desired changes in policy.
Battles with the SAC only further drain an
overworked staff.
We're proud of the work we've
accomplished this year at the News-Letter
and are confident that our readers will
express their support. We're also sure that
the student body would much rather have
the paper in its present form as opposed to
the prospect of no paper at all.
What it comes down to is thiE: if the
News-Letter's funds are withdrawn, there
will be virtually
no student newspaper
here next semester. The SAC may feel that
by withholding funds they can create a
campus mouthpiece. But it seems to us that
we're being victimized by a vocal minority
of student politicians.
We will not compromise our 'policies to
conform with the SAC's narrow conception
of a school newspaper's purpose. It is our
responsibility to produce the finest
newspaper we can. And that we'll continue
to do, SAC or no SAC.

Yesterday we received a letter from SAC
chairman Ron Bialek stating that the SAC
executive committee recommends the
News-Letter be denied SAC funds for the
'76-'77 academic year. All decisions will be
finalized next Wednesday afternoon at a
general SAC meeting in the Great Hall at
5:00 P.M.
The News-Letter's annual expenditures
total approximately $30,000. Eighty per
cent of that sum is obtained through
advertising; the remainder has traditionally
been supplied by the SAC, the group which
funds all Hopkins student organizations. In
order for the paper to survive financially,
the $6,000 is essential.
This is not the first ^time that the
News-Letter has had difficulty in
bargaining for these funds. Last May, after
several heated arguments, the News-Letter
was awarded $5500. In that case, the SAC
questioned whether the paper should have
any paid employees. They insisted that no
staff member, in any capacity, should be
paid for their efforts. They were sure that
most people would continue to work
stripped of salary, out of their dedication
to the paper.
We felt then, as we do now, that this
rationale is not only naive but invalid as
well. First of all, very few staff members
are paid for their services. Those who do
get paid are involved in the technical aspect
of the News-Letter, the behind-the-scenes
drudgery that is necessary to produce any
newspaper. These paid staffers work on
paste-up, typing, distribution and similar
tasks. There is no glory in this kind of
work, no by-lines or picture credits. And
not everyone in this category is paid--we
just can't afford it.
Furthermore, the wages are nowhere
near the king's ransom that the SAC feels
we are handing out. A production assistant
is paid fifteen dollars an issue. Usually they
work from ten in the evening until seven
the next morning. Even with salaries, we
are short on help; if salaries are eliminated,
few will toil for the News—Letter. And
justifiably so.
Unlike most college papers, the
News-Letter offers not a penny to its
editors. No one at the News—letter is
rewarded with academic credit for his or
her work.
This time around with the SAC,
however, there are other conflicts as well.
The SAC executive committee is convinced
the the News-Letter is shirking its
obligation to the student body because of
the content of this year's paper. They say
that the News-Letter should be primarily
an informative publication, one that deals

mainly with student news. Ron Bialek has
said that "the News-Letter's only
accomplishment this year has been to hurt
the jHU undergraduates."
What they really mean to say is that the
News-Letter has ceased to be merely a
publicity organ for the student government
and administration.
In particular, the SAC executive
committee is displeased with the Friday
editions of the News- Letter claiming
that a "magazine-features" format has no
place on a college campus. They describe
the paper as "too literary and cavalier," or
"filled with bullshit." They maintain that a
majority of the student body is dissatisfied
with the Friday News-Letter, suggested by
mythical stacks of leftover papers.
Well, these charges just aren't true. Not
only has the News-Letter increased
circulation this year, but by our estimates
-more people arc reading the News-Letter
today than at any time in its eighty year
history.
We have received,unprecedented acclaim
from a broad mixture of students, faculty,
administration, and community residents.
It is clear to us that the News-Letter is
more popular today than ever before. At
the very least, the constituency of the
News-Letter has changed. Last year's critics
are supporters, while our current detractors
are former friends of the paper. A
newspaper never has unanimous approval.
We have enough problems simply
producing the paper without additional
burdens thrust upon us by the SAC. We
have scores of critics, none of whom are
willing to work at the News-Letter to help
enact their desired changes in policy.
Battles with the SAC only further drain an
overworked staff.
We're proud of the work we've
accomplished this year at the News-Letter
and are confident that our readers will
express their support. We're also sure that
the student body would much rather have
the paper in its present form as opposed to
the prospect of no paper at all.
What it comes down to is thiE: if the
News-Letter's funds are withdrawn, there
will be virtually
no student newspaper
here next semester. The SAC may feel that
by withholding funds they can create a
campus mouthpiece. But it seems to us that
we're being victimized by a vocal minority
of student politicians.
We will not compromise our 'policies to
conform with the SAC's narrow conception
of a school newspaper's purpose. It is our
responsibility to produce the finest
newspaper we can. And that we'll continue
to do, SAC or no SAC.
